title: Ticket #1978: Bad hack in condor_tests causes git annoyance
description:
These files in condor_tests/ have a very stupid piece of code in them: 

cmd_wait_shows-all.run:runcmd("chmod -R 777 .");
cmd_wait_shows-base.run:runcmd("chmod -R 777 .");
cmd_wait_shows-notimeout.run:#runcmd("chmod -R 777 .");
cmd_wait_shows-partial.run:runcmd("chmod -R 777 .");
job_core_priority_van.run:system("chmod -R 777 .");

Since in the new cmake world we must do in source tests, the above causes many tracked files to change permission. Then git status/diff notices this and pollute the system with extraneous changes. It makes it annoying and time consuming to deal with the mess the above chmods leave.

With your cwd in the condor_tests directory, this will fix the above damage that had been done. Hopefully, you don't have changes to any executable files in that directory, in which case this will mess it up, however, it'll be a smaller set of file perms to fix by hand. 

> git diff | grep diff | awk '{print $3}' | sed -e 's@a/src/condor_tests/@@' | xargs chmod 644
remarks:
Better might be the following pipeline assuming you have staged ( git add )ed the files you plan to commit: 

> git ls-files -z -m src/condor_tests | git checkout-index -f -z --stdin

2011-Mar-22 08:47:04 by gthain:
Or, you could just remove the darn chmod from the source. I just did that, with no apparent bad side effects.
